abstract.p: Correction of June 15 article, which described Global Positioning System satellites' orbits incorrectly; article also mischaracterized number of satellite signals that can be used by GPS receiver to determine location

block.p: An article in Circuits on June 15 about the improved accuracy of the Global Positioning System described the orbits of G.P.S. satellites incorrectly. Their orbital positions are very precisely known, but they are not in geosynchronous orbits (maintaining a fixed position relative to the earth).
The article also mischaracterized the number of satellite signals that can be used by a G.P.S. receiver to determine location. Four is the minimum number that can be used, not the maximum.
